perturbation.original_text: Licensee's term of exclusivity with respect to the KOH Video Clips shall expire on October 29, 2005, and Licensee's right and license to distribute the KOH Video Clips shall expire twelve (12) months after the initial theatrical release of the Property "KINGDOM OF HEAVEN".
perturbation.changed_text: Licensee's term of exclusivity with respect to the KOH Video Clips shall expire on October 29, 2005, and Licensee's right and license to distribute the KOH Video Clips shall expire six (6) months after the initial theatrical release of the Property "KINGDOM OF HEAVEN".
perturbation.explanation: Reducing the distribution period to six months after the theatrical release, when standard content licensing agreements in the entertainment industry typically provide for at least twelve months, introduces a contradiction with industry norms and potentially violates reasonable expectations for content monetization. This reduced timeframe could be considered commercially unreasonable, especially given the investment required to distribute the content.
perturbation.contradicted_law: General Contract Law - Implied duty of good faith and fair dealing

perturbation.original_text: Consistent with paragraph 15(c) of the Agreement, Licensee shall forfeit the Guarantee paid to date of ***** dollars (US$*****), and shall immediately pay the remaining Guarantee of ***** dollars (US$*****), equaling a total Guarantee payment by Licensee to Fox of ***** dollars (US$*****) ("Guarantee Forfeiture Payment").
perturbation.changed_text: Consistent with paragraph 15(c) of the Agreement, Licensee shall forfeit the Guarantee paid to date of ***** dollars (US$*****), and shall pay the remaining Guarantee of ***** dollars (US$*****) at Licensee's discretion, equaling a total Guarantee payment by Licensee to Fox of ***** dollars (US$*****) ("Guarantee Forfeiture Payment").
perturbation.explanation: Changing the payment obligation to 'at Licensee's discretion' fundamentally alters the agreed-upon payment terms, making it ambiguous and unenforceable. This change directly contradicts contract law principles which require clear and definite payment schedules. Such ambiguity could lead to disputes over payment obligations and render the clause unenforceable, particularly if the discretion is interpreted as giving the Licensee the right to never pay.
perturbation.contradicted_law: General Contract Law - Enforceability of payment terms

perturbation.original_text: With the exception of Licensee's Royalties payment obligations with respect to all Wireless Products released as of the date of this Amendment, and the obligations set forth in this Amendment, neither party shall have any further obligation under the Agreement, and all claims arising under the Agreement shall be mutually released.
perturbation.changed_text: With the exception of Licensee's Royalties payment obligations with respect to all Wireless Products released as of the date of this Amendment, neither party shall have any further obligation under the Agreement, and all claims arising under the Agreement shall be released without exceptions.
perturbation.explanation: Removing the phrase 'and the obligations set forth in this Amendment' effectively nullifies all the obligations stipulated in the current amendment itself. This creates a direct contradiction: the amendment introduces obligations but then immediately releases both parties from those same obligations. This makes the amendment self-defeating and legally unsound, potentially violating fundamental principles of contract construction that require internal consistency.
perturbation.contradicted_law: General Contract Law - Internal consistency and enforceability
